content: 4.3 GB is very big for an Inbox folder. Inbox folders are not meant to store decades of message traffic and it's better to store messages you want (or you need) to keep in Archive folders. You may also create thematic folders in the Local Folders for long time storing. You may try to rebuild the Global Database https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/rebuilding-global-database Rebuilding the global-messages-db.sqlite file after restart of Thunderbird might take several hours depending on the number of messages in your Thunderbird profile.
creator: Mapenzi

content: 1. Rebuilding the Global Database did not hjælp. 2. How I can Archive bedst my messeges ?
creator: ak8

content:
You may archive messages using Thunderbird's "archive" feature, following explanations in this article https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/archived-messages

Instead of using the archive feature many Thunderbird users create thematic folders in Local Folders to store messages from their Inbox, such as Banking, Invoices, Family, Taxes, ... etc

Remember: after archiving your Inbox messages, whatever the method you'll use, you have to "compact" the Inbox folder: otherwise the Inbox folder will never get smaller https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/compacting-folders

content:
In compose screen, click Options>Return Receipt If menu bar is not visible, press alt key first

Reminder: many users have this feature turned off. There is no assurance that you will receive a receipt, as the process is voluntary. Also, many email providers now disregard the requests, as they are often spam.

content: I presume the account is IMAP. Yes, if you delete locally, the messages are deleted from server. The solution is to copy old messages to Local Folders and then to delete from server. I just responded yesterday to a user with the same problem, but differently worded. I think if you read that thread you will see exactly what to do. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1564841 Any questions, just reply back to this thread. Basically, the steps are - use a filter to identify the old messages and copy them to local folders - repeat the filter, modified from copy to delete, and run filter again to remove from server.
creator: davidsk

content:
gerald12 said
Are these attachments better?

Thank you for the screenshots. Yet regarding the screenshot with the Thunderbird folder pane I still wonder which of your accounts displays only "Sent and Deleted Folders" as you stated in your first message. I do see the @Oakdene account which indeed displays only the Inbox, Deleted and Spam folders. If this is the newly created account and if it is a POP account it is normal that in the beginning only Inbox and Deleted will be displayed. That's the default behaviour with new POP accounts in Thunderbird. A Sent folder will be created when you send your first message from this account, the Spam folder is created when you activate the Spam filter in Account Settings, the Drafts folder when you save a message as a draft, the Archives folder when you archive a message, ....etc

Your second image seems to show the same account set up on your smartphone, and probably it is set up using the IMAP protocol. Now the question is: did you really set up this account in Thunderbird using the IMAP or the POP protocol? If you used POP there will be no automatic synchronisation with the same account on the smartphone. If you used IMAP you'll have to open the "Subscribe" popup - as david already proposed in his first reply - and select the folders to be displayed. You said that you tried but to no avail ... Please show a screen shot with the "Folder list" of your account.

content:
> Thunderbird thinks they are SPAM

TB doesn't know or care about sending spam, so it won't prevent that. The usual suspects are antivirus apps/add-ons.

Do the attachments send in Troubleshoot mode? If not, check your add-ons for one that might be causing the problem.

If they do send, try disabling your antivirus, at least for checking outgoing messages if possible.

content: I am not sure I understand. If this is an IMAP account and you have retention set to 30 days, that keeps messages on PC and on server at the same retention.
creator: davidsk

content: My assumption was just like you said first: In IMAP, sync'ing is _to_ the server. what is deleted from PC is deleted from server. But what is deleted from the server still stays on the local PC. I'm wrong here? Any way of changing this behavivor with IMAP?
creator: asbach2

content: It isn't thunderbird; it' the IMAP protocol. What is on the PC is only for ready reference. the 'official' version of the message is on the server. Easily misunderstood. I have seen people delete messages from server and then log onto thunderbird and discover that the copies on PC suddenly disappeared. It can't be changed. If you need copies locally and want online version deleted, you need to copy to Local Folders prior to deleting.

creator: christ1

content:
Bottom line: I need an answer to blocking the popups. The information I provided related to issues within Yahoo itself was merely background.

Re Yahoo: I'm sure than as you say, *your* account is working fine. But, as the old saying goes, "your mileage may vary." A few weeks ago much of the northeast was buried in snow. Although it was nice and sunny where I live, I am not so naive as to claim that people in NY were not having problems. However an attitude that because Yahoo has many millions of user makes them immune to system problems and breeches is more than just a bit naive.

Smug assurances that there cannot be a problem doesn't make the very real problems go away. I went through a variety of "Thunderbird" solutions including your favorite cookie answers. But none of those revealed any Thunderbird settings issues. I spent countless hours trying to chase down any avenue for support through Yahoo. As soon as the (direct through yahoo) login fails, they parrot on the usual stuff about being sure you didn't mistype this or that. The ultimate answer their "help" system gave was that if unable to resolve the problem after using a series of steps, just create a new Yahoo account! Thanks Yahoo. You say "don't believe everything you read on the internet". Sigh... duh! of course not! but when a user knows that they have not made changes and something stops working, it is reasonable to see if there are reports about any issues with the underlying infrastructure.

Re Thunderbird: In the end your reply not address the basic *Thunderbird* question I asked: how can a user block the cycle of popup messages from Yahoo that happen within Thunderbird hindering usability.


So any defense of Yahoo as an infallible company is not even the core question I asked. I suppose the ultimate answer from Mozilla/Thunderbird will, be... just don't use Thunderbird and you won't get the popups.
creator: agora3

content:

So any defense of Yahoo as an infallible company is not even the core question I asked.

I'm not defending Yahoo in any way. Just stating the facts.
creator: christ1

content:
NEVER received any answer to my question of blocking the cycle of Yahoo login popups. (only that ridiculous denial that there could have been any Yahoo-based problem) But fortunately whatever (denied) server drama Yahoo had been experiencing was ultimately resolved and yesterday and I was able to log in to Yahoo (both directly and through Thunderbird) using the previous passwords that had worked before the Yahoo accounts tanked.

(Of course as a security precaution, once my accounts on Yahoo became accessible again, I changed the passwords "just in case" they had been compromised during the Yahoo "event". Well, that and because it's good to change passwords from time to time)

That resolution within Yahoo resolved the immediate issue of the popups. (however of course it would have been useful to have actually had a response to how to block the popups occurring for the NEXT time Yahoo dives!!!)

content:
Homer712 said
Just looking to have replies under the original emails, I believe this is called threads?

Do you want your replies under the received messages, or the replies of other senders? If it's the former, that is usually called 'conversation mode'. Right-click a message, Open, Open Message in Conversation. Or, check the box 'Place replies in the folder...' in the Copies & Folders section of Account Settings.

content:
Homer712 said
I now need to get back to where I was before making all these changes. I’ve looked in the user profile and there’s a file called “prefs.js” (/Users/homer/Library/Thunderbird/Profiles/uf1ofj9l.default-release/prefs.js). I’ve got backups, if I replace this file from a backup, will I then be back to before I posted this issue.

I am a long time Mac und Thunderbird user, I read the whole discussion but I still wonder what you want to accomplish. I think that sfhowes was right when he wrote that you want your replies under the received messages, that is both, received messages and your replies, displayed in the same thread in Inbox. But you told him that this didn't work This is possible, he told you how to do it, I just tested it and it works for me (see images)

Closing Thunderbird and replacing your actual prefs.js file in the Thunderbird profile folder with a prefs.js file from one of your profile backups will probably do what you want to accomplish. But you have to be aware that prefs modifications made in the meantime will no longer be working...

content:
Try setting your fonts for viewing and writing this way:

- go to TB menu > Settings > General > Language & Fonts > Fonts > click 'Advanced' button

- at the top, set 'Fonts for:' to Latin if it isn't already

- change Proportional and Monospace fonts/sizes to your liking

- set Minimum font size to 14

- at the top, change set 'Fonts for:' to Other Writing Systems

- repeat the process of changing fonts/sizes

- at the bottom, make sure 'Allow messages to use other fonts' is disabled if desired > OK > close the popup
